Type & Description: Portfolio notes, longer description than allowed in portfolio name
Account group, could use to group multiple accounts (e.g. for binders)
Account status. Aside from predefined values, you can use other single character values for user specific purposes
Flexible field that is stored in FlexiAcc table in ModifierName = ZZZ
Policy layer status. Aside from predefined values, other single character values for user specific purposes can be used.
Policy inception date - in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD
Policy expiry date - in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD
Line of business (defined at policy level)
Insurance company share of the policy layer. Values between 0 to 1 (e.g. 12% entered as 0.12)
Policy layer limit (always treated as amount)
Policy layer attachment point (always treated as amount)
For perils with an inherent event duration, the insurance contract may contain an hours clause that limits the time in which claims can be added up and assigned to one event
Policy blanket limit code (annual aggregate only)
Code that represents how, and for which coverages, pay-outs are triggered.
Number between 1 and 10 that is used to sort the step function in the correct order.
Refers to PayoutBuilding, PayoutContents, PayoutBuildingContents. Payout can be % TIV, % Loss, a monetary amount, or % Limit.
Refers to TriggerStart and TriggerEnd fields which could be specified as a % TIV, % Loss or a monetary amount.
Starting value of the building damage range over which the corresponding pay-out(s) should be made.
Ending value of the building damage range over which the corresponding pay-out(s) should be made.
Building deductible that can be used, for example, to account for fire policies before applying step functions.
Pay-out amount for the building losses for this step. If a ramp policy then it represents the start payout value.

Pay-out amount for the end-point building losses for this ramp. This field should only be used if you have a ramp policy to indicate the end of the building payout. Otherwise, it should be left blank.
Starting value of the content damage range over which the corresponding pay-out(s) should be made.
Ending value of the content damage range over which the corresponding pay-out(s) should be made.
Content deductible that can be used, for example, to account for fire policies before applying step functions.
Pay-out amount for the contents losses for this step. If a ramp policy then it represents the start payout value.

Pay-out amount for the end-point contents losses for this ramp. This field should only be used if you have a ramp policy to indicate the end of the contents payout. Otherwise, it should be left blank.
Starting value of the building and content damage range over which the corresponding pay-out(s) should be made.
Ending value of the building and content damage range over which the corresponding pay-out(s) should be made.
Building and contents deductible that can be used, for example, to account for fire policies before applying step functions.
Pay-out amount for the building and contents losses for this step. If a ramp policy then it represents the start payout value.

Pay-out amount for the end-point building and contents losses for this ramp. This field should only be used if you have a ramp policy to indicate the end of the building and contents payout. Otherwise, it should be left blank.
Pay-out limit for building and contents

A factor that is applied to main coverage loss for extra expenses. This value, entered as a decimal, should be the same for all steps for a policy contract and must be a value >=0. For example, 0.12 for 12%.
A limit that applies to the total extra expense loss

A factor for a conditional coverage which tends to apply to all steps and is to cover Debris Removal. This value, entered as a decimal, should be the same for all steps for a policy contract and must be a value >=0. For example, 0.12 for 12%.
Minimum replacement value for which pay-outs to the corresponding damage range will be allowed.
Percentage factor used to scale calculated losses. This value, entered as a decimal, should be the same for all steps for a policy contract and must be a value >0. For example, 0.12 for 12%.
Indicates whether the pay-out is limited by the actual ground-up loss.
Flexible field that is stored in FlexiPol table in ModifierName = ZZZ
Condition number identifies a unique set of condition financial terms applicable to one or more CondTag's.
Condition priority: specifies the order in which special conditions apply if multiple conditions apply to one location.
Special condition other building deductible code
Special condition other building deductible type
Special condition minimum other building deductible
Special condition maximum other building deductible
Special condition other building limit code
Special condition other building limit type
Correlation Group: indicates which locations should be correlated between each other in Oasis LMF.
Whether the location in LocGroup is the primary building in the group
Whether property is occupied by a tenant or not
Location inception date - in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD
Location expiry date - in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD
Completeness percentage of the construction project at this location. The project completion percentage is by the cost of the project. Values between 0 to 1 (e.g. 12% enterd as 0.12)
Construction project completion date - in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD
Country code (based on ISO3166 alpha-2 codes)
Postcode: the highest resolution postcode most often used. (e.g. 5 digit zip for the US).
Code representing typically the largest sub-division in a country (e.g. State code). See AreaCode Values sheet for details.
Name relating to the AreaCode (e.g. State name). See AreaCode Values sheet for details.

Geography scheme: Descriptor of the geography scheme used in relation to the geography name in the corresponding GeogName field (e.g. PC4). The 'XX' must be changed to an integer (GeogScheme1......> GeogScheme30 (max) etc) and the user can specify values in addition to those listed in the GeogScheme values list, but user defined scheme values must start with 'X'.
Geography name: Descriptor of the geographical area, using the scheme referenced in the corresponding GeogScheme field (e.g. SO31)
Address match from geocoder: indicating the resolution that the latitude / longitude represents
Geocode quality (values between 0 and 1 e.g. 80% is entered as 0.8)
Company name / version of geocoder. Free text field.

Number of storeys (-1 = Unknown No. storeys - low rise), (-2 = Unknown No. storeys - mid rise), (-3 = Unknown No. storeys = high rise). Can be used with occupancy types where the number of storeys are unknown.
Number of buildings. Default to 1 but user should enter '0' if unknown.
Floor area: the total area across all floors
Units in which FloorArea is specified
Flexible field that is stored in FlexiLoc table in ModifierName = ZZZ
Other Building Insured Value (primarily aimed at specific US policies). For motor exposures, use this field for TIV along with appropriate motor construction code.
BI period of indemnity (in days, in increments of 0.5 days). Default value = 365 (1 year).
Gross premium amount at location level
Insurance tax amount at location level
Ground-Up non-cat loss value prior to the application of non-cat policy terms
Percentage of risk that the insurer covers for this location. Values between 0 to 1 (e.g. 12% enterd as 0.12). Usually used in binders or offshore.
Pay-out basis for the claim (whether depreciation is taken into account). ACV = RCV - depreciation.
User defined reinsurance tag to provide a further option for specifying reinsurance scope
Year the building was upgraded (4 digit year)
Storm leakage percentage (0% to 100%) for Wind only policies
Percent sprinklered. Values between 0 and 1 inclusive (0.5 = 50%); -999 is unknown
Code that represents the material used to cover the roof
Year the roof was last replaced (4 digit year)
Code that represents the shape of the roof
captures if mechanical or electric equipment is braced on the roof and the impact this modifier will have on the losses.
Captures the impact roof maintenance has on the losses
Code that identifies items mounted on the roof, such as A/C units, skylights, or dormers
Code that represents the materials used to construct the roof deck
Code that represents the slope of the roof
Code that represents the connections used to secure the roof support system to the walls
Code that represents the connections used to secure the roof deck to the underlying roof support system
Code that represents the connections used to secure the roof covering to the roof deck
Code that represents the type of glass used in the building
Code that represents the type of web used for H-shaped steel
Code that indicates if there is structural weakness at any floor.  First floor garages and taller first floors are likely to exhibit soft-story behaviour.
Code that defines if there is a basement and if so whether it is finished or unfinished
Indicates the number of basement levels in a structure (supports up to 5 levels; for more than 5, enter 5).
Code that represents the wind protection systems used on the windows
Code that represents the construction type of the building's foundation
Code that represents a structure that is physically attached to the building, such as garage or balcony
Code for the appurtenant building, such as shed or detached garage
Captures whether mechanical or electrical equipment are present on the ground level of a building and impact it has on losses
Identifies where mechanical or electrical equipment is held in place by bracing
Refers to the impact the quality of the flashing or coping on a roof has on losses
Code that represents the shape of the building
Identifies vertical irregularities, overhangs and setbacks in the building design
Code that represents the distance to the closest structure, which if not adequate, can cause the two structures to collide during earthquake shaking
Code that represents the amount of decorative elements attached to the exterior of a building
Presence of a seismic base isolation system
Presence of retro fit connectivity between walls and floor for retro fit buildings
Presence of cripple walls on the first floor or frame buildings
Connection of frame to foundation with or without bolts
Code that indicates if there are short columns in the building
Captures signs of damage from prior earthquakes
The presence and material of exterior building cladding
Height of the lowest floor (above ground) of the building with respect to local ground elevation (NOT relative to datum). First floor in the US is identical to ground floor in Europe.
Code for the unit of measure used to express FirstFloorHeight
Datum reference for the elevation fields (e.g. NAVD88; WGS84)

Flood or Windstorm - Elevation of the local ground surface at the building at this location. This field represents the elevation of the grade (local ground surface) with respect to the datum (e.g. NAVD88).
Code for the unit of measure used to express the GroundElevation
Code that indicates if there are rooftop tanks on the adjoining higher buildings
Indicates whether there are multiple lateral load resisting elements, such as frames or shear walls
Interior wall partitions or chimneys made from URM
Wind resistant doors, doors with a certain rating of hurricane protection
Code that represents the layout of structural elements that can lead to torsional loads
Mechanical or electrical equipment at the side
Contents relative vulnerability to windstorm or tornado
Code that identifies whether small debris are present within 200 meters of the structure

Number of floors in the building that are occupied (separated by semi-colons). Each floor occupied is separated by a semi-colon. Ranges are not accepted. 0 = ground floor, -1 = first level of basement, -2 = second level of basement; 1 = first floor, 2 = second floor, etc.
Height of any site specific flood defenses protecting the property with respect to local ground elevation (NOT to datum).
Code for the unit of measure used to express the FloodDefenseHeight
Shows if building is vulnerable to floating debris

Water surface elevation (relative to datum - this is NOT a flood depth) corresponding to a flood having a 1% probability of being equaled or exceeded in a given year. A value of -999 for this field represents unknown/default.
Code for the unit of measure used to express the BaseFloodElevation
Field for third party valuation data
Secondary modifier coding density of trees adjacent to structure
Code that indicates if the structure has a chimney and, if so, the height of the chimney
Describes the susceptibility of the packaging of a risk to the peril
Describes the level of protection from the specific peril
The salvage potential of a particular product
Where the specie element is stored
Number of days cargo is kept at port or the duration of an exhibition. Values between 0 to 1825 (up to 5 years). Default = 365.
Code that represents the percentage of external walls that consist of brick veneer.
Indicates whether the building is in compliance with the FEMA flood zone requirements in both design and construction
Standard of flood protection return period; values from 0-10,000
Code that indicates if the building has a multi-story hall
Code that represents the percentage of exterior walls that are open (i.e. have windows or doors)
Code that indicates whether the service equipment is protected from flood
The height of the taller than usual one-story building (e.g. gymnasium, auditorium, church, etc.)
Reinsurance layer for information / ordering purposes
Reinsurance inception date - in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD
Reinsurance expiry date - in ISO 8601 format: YYYY-MM-DD
Reinsurance ceded percentage. Used mainly in surplus treaties. Applies before other reinsurance terms. Values between 0 to 1 (e.g. 12% entered as 0.12)
Reinsurance reverse franchise - a value of loss that, if exceeded, results in no payment being made for this event from the reinsurer to insurer.
Maximum amount payable under this treaty during the AggPeriod
The aggregate monetary amount during a given AggPeriod that the resinured retains under this treaty
Aggregate period associated with the aggregate limits and attachments (in days). Default value = 365 (1 year)

Percentage of the limit that has been placed in the reinsurance market. The main percentage used for reinsurance treaties other than surplus. Applies after other reinsurance terms. Values between 0 to 1 (e.g. 12% entered as 0.12)
Reinsurance inuring priority capturing the order in which reinsurance contracts apply. Treaties with lower number inuring priorities apply first.

Reinstatement charge as %; semi-colon separated if different for each reinstatement (e.g. 1-free, 2-50%, 3-100% should be entered as: 0;0.5;1). If all reinstatements are the same, then just one number is sufficient (e.g. 3 reinstatements at 100% should be entered as 1)

Deemed percent placed, used to represent notional contracts or any part of the contract being notional. For fully notional contracts, enter 1 (i.e. 100%). For partially placed contracts, enter any value between 0 and 1. For real contracts, enter 0.
Reinsurance exchange rate (as the contractual reinsurance rate can be different from the actual exchange rates used for policies and locations)
The percentage of a treaty that a given reinsurer may write. Values between 0 to 1 (e.g. 12% entered as 0.12).
A flag to indicate if reinsurance contract dates or  policy inception / expiry dates are to be considered when calculating losses (Y) or ignored (N).
Reinsurance number to link with ReinsInfo file
Portfolio number: used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Account number:  used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Policy number:  used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Location group name:  used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Location number:  used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Cedant name:  used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Producer name:  used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Line of business:  used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Country code: used for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Reinsurance tag: user defined field to for defining treaty scope in the reinsurance scope file
Ceded percentage (for 12%, enter 0.12). Within the reinsurance scope file, CededPercent should only be entered for surplus share treaties.
Code to indicate the definition of 'risk' for the per-risk terms in this particular treaty (or portion of the treaty)
Identifies whether a risk is static or dynamic (moves from location to location)
Flags whether a condition is a policy restriction
Identifies a group of locations which are subject to one or more conditions.
The OED schema version of the file - 'major, minor, patch' format i.e. (2.0.0)
Agggrated Data based on NumberOfBuildings field
0 = no soil information, 1 = time averaged shear-wave velocity to 30m depth (vs30 (m/s))
The value associated with the SoilType and the corresponding unit
Total number of occupants at a location (e.g., residents, employees, visitors)
Number of occupants aged under 5 years
Number of occupants aged over 65 years
Number of occupants who identify as non-binary or other gender
Number of occupants classed as living in an urban area
Number of occupants classed as living in a rural area
Number of occupants classed as living in poverty
Number of occupants with refugee status
Number of occupants classed as unemployed
Number of occupants with a disability
Original currency in which the business has been written before any conversions
Rate of exchange used to convert the terms from OriginalCurrency
Depth of water for offshore structures (in metres)

Length of line element associated with point location. Intended for line-assets, such as roads, railways and cables. Such an asset can be defined as a series of points along its length, and the 'Length' field describes the length associated with each point. E.g. if a road is coded as points at 2km intervals, then the 'Length' value is 2, and the TIV represents the value for that 2km stretch of road.

The electrical capacity (e.g. in MW) associated with an infrastructure asset. Intended for power generation and power transmission assets. E.g. power stations, turbines, cables, etc.
Provide the generating capacity of each asset (e.g. for a turbine, this is the capacity of the turbine, not the windfarm).
ID allowing custom location level vulnerability to be captured
Geometry of the location: refer to http://postgis.net/workshops/postgis-intro/geometries.html
Code provision for energy, water and communication infrastructure
Anchorage of for energy, water and communication infrastructure
Voltage of energy infrastructure (applicable to substations, generation facilities and transmission)
Capacity of water pumping and treatment plants, in MGD (Millions gallons per day)
Insurance company share of the account loss. Values between 0 to 1 (e.g. 12% entered as 0.12)
Company identification scheme. Eg. DUNS, LEI. See 'OtherValues'
Company identifier related to the CompanyIDScheme
Year that insured entity founded to support company identification (YYYY format)
Main street address of insured entity
Postal code of main address for insured entity
City of main address for insured entity
Country code for the country of domicile of the insured entity - see 'CountryValues'
Area code of main address for insured entity - see 'AreaCodeValues'
Industry scheme i.e NAISC, USSIC, UKSIC. See 'OtherValues'
Industry code from the IndustryScheme - see 'IndustryCodeValues'
Vintage of Industry code used (YYYY format)
Concise industry description (associated with IndustryCode or free form)
Most recent estimate of number of employees
Most recent estimate for annual total gross income (not profit)
Currency for AnnualRevenue in three digit format. See 'CurrencyValues'
Gross Profit Margin of company in percentage (0.1 = 10%)
Policy Deductible (monetary value for all coverages - non-property)
If not unique indicates policy stacking (e.g. policies part of same insurance tower)
Limit Currency for all Coverages -  see 'CurrencyValues'
Deductible Currency for all currencies -  see 'CurrencyValues'
List of coverages in policy - see 'CoverageValues'
Customer Relationship Management vendor code - see 'OtherValues'
Cadence of patches to the 'main system' - 0-Unknown/1-Never/2-Daily/3-Weekly/4-Monthly/5-Annually/6-Ad-hoc
Cadence of back-up of the 'main servers' - 0-Unknown/1-Never/2-Daily/3-Weekly/4-Monthly/5-Annually/6-Ad-hoc
AreaName of main address for insured entity - see 'AreaCodeValues'
Concise class of business description for the policy coverage (free form)
Concise territorial description for the policy coverage (free form)
Options: 0-Claims Made or 1-Losses Occurring or 2-Occurrence Reported
Is the policy coverage extended to subsidiaries of the insured party; Options: 0-No or 1-Yes
Options: 0-Outside the limit, 1-Inside the limit or 2-Not Covered
BI waiting period defined at policy level (in days)
BI period of indemnity defined at policy level (in days, in increments of 0.5 days). Default value = 365 (1 year).
Defines whether a soil is susceptible to liquefaction or not.
Full legal name of insured party
